intro: Salvia bogotensis subsp. suratensis, commonly known as the Bogotá sage, is a perennial herb native to the Andean regions of South America. It is characterized by its tall, erect stems and clusters of violet-blue flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant has lance-shaped leaves with a slightly hairy texture, and it thrives in well-drained, rocky soils. It is often found in high-altitude grasslands and is valued for its ornamental appeal and medicinal properties. Due to its specific habitat requirements, it is considered a rare and endangered species in its native range.
